The question of impeachment goes beyond party. It is about standing up for our democracy.

We cannot ignore this president‚Äôs actions. I was elected to support and defend our Constitution against all threats, foreign and domestic. That is what I will continue to do.

I believe in bipartisanship, and my time in public service has been built on the ideal that we can get more done together than we ever could alone. I've worked with my colleagues across the aisle to improve our infrastructure, healthcare, environment and more‚Äîthis won't change.

If anyone else did these things, they would face legal consequences. I‚Äôve read the #MuellerReport, heard Mueller's testimony, seen the continued efforts of administration officials to dodge subpoenas.

The president knew the rules and he broke them‚Äîhe cannot be above the law.

We have seen Donald Trump and his allies invite meddling into our elections. We have watched our nation's moral fabric rip apart. We have learned that the president evaded truth, encouraged his staff to lie repeatedly to investigators and engaged in obstruction on 10 occasions.

Our nation has seen and heard things from this president that have no place in our democracy.

I believe it is time to open an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump.

Read my full statement: https://carbajal.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=537

I oppose proposals that would encourage even more migrants to risk coming, like decriminalizing border crossing or giving undocumented migrants health care. But the decent people now fleeing violence & wanting a better life for their kids shouldn't be treated like a threat. (17)

And finally, let us secure the border while passing the comprehensive immigration reform that had huge bipartisan support in Congress -- before some of my GOP colleagues grew afraid of the man who took over their Party. (16)

Here's a better answer:
- restore aid to Central America that Trump recklessly cut
- make asylum a viable option instead of ending it, so more migrants go the legal route
- work with communities like El Paso to manage the flow in a humane & dignified way, as they want to do! (15)

We'll be in the worst of possible worlds: inflicting suffering on innocent people, betraying America's decades-old commitment to help people fleeing persecution, without even denting the humanitarian crisis at the border. (14)

Setting aside the immorality of using cruelty and chaos to deter migration, it is not working. People are still coming. If taking children from their parents didn't deter migration, proposals to make asylum even harder won't work either. (13)

Meanwhile, we've placed barricades at lawful crossings that impede trade and hurt our economy. Most of the vehicle lanes at the busiest commercial crossing in El Paso are marked "cerrado," closed. (12) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EBALpwIUwAAV8qu.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EBALpwHU0AI_I68.jpg

Detention conditions are better, thanks in part to pressure and $ from Congress. But charity-run facilities in Mexico still provide more than those run by the government of the wealthiest country in the world. Here's the sleeping area in one shelter in Juarez. (11) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EBALmsoU0AAeKpK.jpg

For example, systematic child separation was stopped by the courts, but kids are still being taken from extended family members like grandparents, and even from parents who have committed minor legal infractions. (10)

Trump's main immigration adviser, Stephen Miller, has said that the policy is to present migrants with "multiple unsolvable dilemmas" so that they never try for asylum. https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/immigration/stephen-miller-wants-use-border-agents-screen-migrants-cut-number-n1035831 (9)

This sounds crazy, until you consider the one constant in all of the administration's border policies: to make the process of lawful asylum as painful as possible so that migrants are deterred from coming. (8)

DHS officers admitted that the policy of pushing back lawful asylum seekers is incentivizing unlawful crossing & human smuggling. Ironically, families caught crossing unlawfully have a better chance of being released to  families in the U.S. than those who play by the rules! (7)

We tell migrants who ask for asylum to do it lawfully, at a recognized border crossing. But when they do, 100% are pushed back to danger. So, unsurprisingly, more and more are crossing between border posts in desperation. This week, two died in the attempt. (6)

This new policy forces everyone who asks for asylum at a lawful border crossing to go straight back to Mexico, where they wait for months for a hearing, easy prey for extortionist gangs. So we've just pushed the misery across the border, and tried to wash our hands of it. (5)
The overcrowding in holding facilities is gone, but that's due to a new policy that goes by the Orwellian name "Migrant Protection Protocols." (4)

This is the reality we saw: people here, from the @CBPWestTexas to the amazingly welcoming communities of El Paso and Juarez are trying to treat migrants with pragmatism & humanity, but policies made in Washington are causing chaos and pain. (3)
Yesterday a Border Patrol officer told me: "99% of the people I catch, I'd be happy to have as my neighbors." He added: "The bluster from Washington makes everything harder." (2)
